structured_info.title_en: Recent Trends in Compact Planar Antennas at 5G Sub-6 GHz and mm Wave Frequency Bands for Automotive Wireless Applications: A Review
structured_info.abstract: 5G wireless communication offers higher channel capacity, high data rate, sufficient bandwidth, enhanced coverage, and reliable link as compared to the previous generation mobile networks. Also, 5G becomes more relevant with the recent launches of low earth orbit satellites by various ventures like starlink, amazon, one web, etc. As these satellites have heights up to the range from 300 km to 1000 km, the free space path loss decreases drastically which in turn improves the signal reliability and efficient communication at dead spots. With these advancements, antenna researchers have the freedom to design compact, easy to manufacture, with adequate gain user equipment terminal antennas which can be easily integrated in the modern passenger car body. This paper will focus on the recent development in the design considerations of the compact antenna design at sub-6 GHz (n78 frequency band) and mm wave (n278 frequency band) according to 3gpp standards. This manuscript also discusses various design specifications like selection of material for antennas, design complexity, feeding methods, fabrication and measurement challenges and performance parameters which include reflection coefficient, gain, polarization, axial ratio, cross polarization discrimination, radiation efficiency, radiation pattern shape, etc. The proposed antenna design considerations will facilitate the possible integration into the various parts of the car body according to the recent vehicular applications for uninterrupted communication.
structured_info.methodology: Literature review and comparative analysis of existing compact planar antenna designs, including microstrip patch antennas, CPW feeding structures, sequential rotation techniques for arrays, and parametric optimizations, focusing on circular polarization, gain enhancement, and automotive integration challenges.
structured_info.conclusion: Circular polarization is essential for reliable satellite communication in vehicles; antenna arrays enhance gain but face mutual coupling challenges; compactness is critical for automotive integration, though embedding affects performance due to material dielectric properties; future innovations should focus on multilayer designs, metasurfaces, and shared aperture configurations.

analysis.Overview: The paper reviews recent advancements in compact planar antennas for 5G sub-6 GHz and mm wave bands, focusing on design methodologies, performance parameters, and integration challenges in automotive wireless applications, such as satellite and terrestrial communications.
Background_and_Motivation: Addresses challenges in 5G/6G automotive communications, including high data rates, low free space path loss for reliable links in rural/mobile settings, and the need for compact antennas due to low earth orbit satellite advancements.

Motivated by the urgency to design miniaturized, high-gain antennas with circular polarization to ensure uninterrupted connectivity in vehicles, leveraging reduced orbital heights from ventures like Starlink.
Argues necessity through link budget calculations showing distance and antenna gain as critical factors; urgency is emphasized by growing automotive applications requiring embedded antennas.
Relates specific antenna design problems to broader 5G/6G challenges by highlighting how compact antennas enable efficient integration into cars, enhancing global connectivity.
Contributes to electromagnetics, antenna engineering, and interdisciplinary fields involving wireless communications and automotive technology.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts: (1) Circular Polarization - achieved by exciting orthogonal modes for signal reliability; (2) Antenna Arrays - used to boost gain via sequential feeding; (3) MIMO Configuration - enhances channel capacity but requires isolation.
Logical network: Circular polarization reduces multipath fading, arrays increase gain to improve data rates, and MIMO supports concurrent operations, all enabling compact automotive integration.

Assumptions: Antenna miniaturization is feasible with high-index substrates; embedding in car materials (e.g., plastic) alters performance but can be optimized; circular polarization purity (axial ratio <3 dB) is achievable.
Contribution type: Synthesizes existing knowledge, identifies trends, and proposes innovations like metasurfaces; serves as a comprehensive reference for advancing antenna design in electromagnetics.
Methodology: Core methods include reviewing diverse antenna designs (e.g., microstrip patches, CPW-fed structures), parametric optimization, and experimental validation of parameters like impedance bandwidth and axial ratio.

Novelty in sequential rotation feeding and metasurface integration; applicability to automotive contexts is high; rationality lies in addressing real-world integration challenges through literature synthesis.

Data sources: Existing studies from cited papers; characteristics include antenna dimensions, gains, bandwidths; preprocessing involves design simulations and fabrication; representativeness is ensured by covering sub-6 GHz/mm wave bands.
Experimental design rigor: Evaluated via tables comparing metrics (e.g., peak gain, bandwidth); adequacy confirmed through measurement validations in cited works, but lacks original experiments.
Follows electromagnetic theory paradigms, affecting perspective by grounding analysis in practical antenna design principles rather than abstract models.
Results: Key results: Reviewed antennas show wide impedance bandwidths (e.g., up to 5400 MHz), axial ratio bandwidths (e.g., 484 MHz for CP), and gains (e.g., 11.5 dBic for arrays); automotive integrations achieve data rates up to 6 Mbit/s.
Significance: Demonstrates feasibility of compact designs for 5G; reliability from experimental consistency; stability concerns noted in embedding effects, mitigated via optimization.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Overall structure: Introduction → Link budget → Antenna designs (single elements and arrays) → Automotive challenges → Terrestrial networks → Innovations → Future insights → Conclusion.
Key steps: Establish need via satellite advancements; analyze CP antenna designs; extend to arrays; discuss integration issues; suggest innovations; conclude with implications.
Strengths: Comprehensive, logically sequenced; weaknesses: Limited critique of cited works. Addresses rebuttals (e.g., size-gain trade-offs) by proposing compromises and multilayer solutions.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Thorough review of recent trends; innovations like metasurface use for gain enhancement; practical automotive integration insights.
Limitations: Focuses on planar antennas, excluding other types; methodology constrained by material availability and mutual coupling in arrays.
Theoretical paradigm constraints: Reliance on electromagnetic design principles may limit exploration of novel materials or AI-based optimizations, bounding conclusions to existing frameworks.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Role: Positions within electromagnetics discourse as a consolidator of antenna design advancements for automotive 5G, bridging theory and application.
Terminology: Technical (e.g., 'axial ratio', 'free space path loss'); tone authoritative; rhetorical strategies include comparative tables and emphasis on challenges to highlight contributions.
Authority building: Cites 73 references to contextualize work; motivations include establishing credibility and underscoring the review's comprehensiveness.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Main conclusions: Circular polarization is vital for reliability; arrays and MIMO improve performance; integration faces challenges like material effects and space constraints; future requires multilayer designs and beamforming.
Future research suggestions: Explore metasurfaces for gain; optimize shared aperture antennas; investigate EMC compliance; enhance MIMO metrics like ECC for 5G reliability.
